title: The history of swimming
intro: Swimming has many health benefits and since ancient times has been used to promote strength and wellbeing. But swimming’s not just about exercise – there’s far more to it beneath the surface as we’ll be finding out in this programme on the history of swimming. Neil and Georgina talk about the topic and teach you related vocabulary along the way.
this_week_question: Someone who did enjoy swimming was the poet, Lord Byron. He wrote poems popularising the sport and in 1810 swam the Hellespont, a stretch of water separating Europe from Asia. But in which modern country can the Hellespont be found?
a) Greece b) Cyprus c) Turkey
Listen to the programme to find out the answer.

vocab.desc: to not follow what everyone else is doing
shocking or embarrassing because it shows too much of the body
stay away from school without permission

transcript.author: Neil
transcript.text: Hello. This is 6 Minute English from BBC Learning English. I’m Neil.

transcript.author: Georgina
transcript.text: And I’m Georgina.

transcript.author: Neil
transcript.text: Can you swim, Georgina?

transcript.author: Georgina
transcript.text: I can, Neil. I learned to swim as a child and now I enjoy swimming for exercise and to relax.

transcript.author: Neil
transcript.text: In the summer hundreds of keen swimmers, like Georgina, head off to swimming pools, lakes and beaches to take a dip – an informal idiom meaning ‘go for a swim’.

transcript.author: Georgina
transcript.text: Swimming has many health benefits and since ancient times has been used to promote strength and wellbeing.

transcript.author: Neil
transcript.text: But swimming’s not just about exercise – there’s far more to it beneath the surface as we’ll be finding out in this programme on the history of swimming.

transcript.author: Georgina
transcript.text: Although evidence suggests that ancient Mediterranean people dived eagerly into temple pleasure pools, lakes and the sea, other cultures have swum against the tide – another swimming idiom there, Neil - meaning ‘not to follow what everyone else is doing’.

transcript.author: Neil
transcript.text: Someone who did enjoy swimming was the poet, Lord Byron. He wrote poems popularising the sport and in 1810 swam the Hellespont, a stretch of water separating Europe from Asia. But in which modern country can the Hellespont be found - that’s my quiz question, Georgina. Is it: a) Greece? b) Cyprus?, or c) Turkey?

transcript.author: Georgina
transcript.text: I think Lord Byron visited Istanbul, so I’ll say c) Turkey.

transcript.author: Georgina
transcript.text: According to historian and swimming enthusiast, Professor Kevin Dawson, the rise of Christian beliefs discouraged swimming, as he explains here to BBC World Service programme, The Forum:

transcript.author: Kevin Dawson
transcript.text: You have some beliefs that water is this unsafe space, unnatural space for human beings… it’s a perpetuation of the chaos that existed before God created land, or that water is a mechanism for punishment like the Great Flood story or pharaoh’s army being destroyed in the Red Sea… but then there’s also beliefs that swimming is immodest … most people at the time swam nude and so church officials discouraged swimming because they felt that it lead to immodest behaviour.

transcript.author: Neil
transcript.text: As well as being considered unsafe or chaotic, swimming was seen as immodest – shocking because it shows too much of the body.

transcript.author: Georgina
transcript.text: This was because most people at the time swam nude – naked, without clothes.

transcript.author: Neil
transcript.text: Another place with a long history of swimming is the remote Maldives Islands in the Indian Ocean.

transcript.author: Georgina
transcript.text: In the Maldives, access to shallow, warm sea-water lakes called lagoons makes it an unbeatable place for swimming.

transcript.author: Neil
transcript.text: But even on a tropical island, things haven’t always gone swimmingly as diver and Maldives resident, Mikael Rosen, told BBC World Service programme, The Forum:

transcript.author: Georgina
transcript.text: Listen for the reason Mikael gives for the change in people’s attitudes to swimming in the Maldives:

transcript.author: Mikael Rosen
transcript.text: Most citizens of the Maldives have half a mile to a lukewarm lagoon. Given that, they could be world leaders in swimming, but in the 1960s the government recruited a lot of teachers from India, Sri Lanka. They didn’t know anything about the water culture and they noticed that the young students playing hooky – they were in the lagoons, and swimming soon got frowned upon, but now the government and the local organisations – they try to reclaim swimming.

transcript.author: Georgina
transcript.text: Did you hear the reason Mikael gave, Neil?

transcript.author: Neil
transcript.text: Yes, he said that young students were playing hooky to go swimming in the lagoons. Play hooky is an informal way of saying ‘stay away from school without permission’.

transcript.author: Georgina
transcript.text: Right, and that meant swimming quickly got frowned upon , or disapproved of.

transcript.author: Neil
transcript.text: It seems a bit unfair since there was already a strong culture of swimming in the Maldives which the arriving teachers didn’t fully appreciate.

transcript.author: Georgina
transcript.text: Well, I know which I’d rather do – sit in a classroom or swim in a warm tropical lagoon!

transcript.author: Neil
transcript.text: Swimming, right? But then you would never have learned about Lord Byron…

transcript.author: Georgina
transcript.text: Yes, in your quiz question you asked me about Lord Byron swimming the Hellespont, a stretch of water separating Europe from Asia.

transcript.author: Neil
transcript.text: I asked you in which country the Hellespont can be found. Is it: a) Greece? b) Cyprus? or c) Turkey? What did you say?

transcript.author: Georgina
transcript.text: I said c) Turkey. Was I right?

transcript.author: Neil
transcript.text: Yes, you were, Georgina! The Hellespont, also known as the Straits of Dardanelles, is a six-kilometre-wide stretch of water in Turkey.

transcript.author: Georgina
transcript.text: Let’s recap the vocabulary from this programme on swimming, which some people informally call taking a dip.

transcript.author: Neil
transcript.text: Someone who swims against the tide refuses to do what everyone else is doing.

transcript.author: Georgina
transcript.text: In the past, swimming was considered immodest - shocking because it showed too much of the body.

transcript.author: Neil
transcript.text: Another word for naked or not wearing any clothes is nude.

transcript.author: Georgina
transcript.text: Children who play hooky stay away from school without permission.

transcript.author: Neil
transcript.text: And finally, if something is ' frowned upon' it’s disapproved of.

transcript.author: Georgina
transcript.text: That’s all for our dive into the deep end of the vocabulary of swimming. As we’ve discovered, there’s plenty of idioms and expressions relating to swimming and water!

transcript.author: Neil
transcript.text: And check us out on Facebook, Twitter, and Instagram.

transcript.author: Georgina

transcript.author: Neil

transcript.author: Georgina
